pageData.text: Periodic trends and the formation of the <button class='glossary-text'>periodic table</button> are studied by organizing three different sets of cards, deciding how to organize the <button class='glossary-text'>elements</button> and comparing the organization system with the arrangements of other students. In addition, the organizing criteria for the designated systems are compared with those of the modern periodic table. Finally, elemental data are graphed to identify periodic trends.

pageData.text: The International Union for Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) was charged with establishing rules that would apply to naming new <button class='glossary-text'>elements</button>. For example, the name must be a word that changes as little as possible between different languages; or names should originate from a mythological concept or character, a mineral, a place or region, a characteristic of the new element, or a scientist. These rules were established in 2002, and the honor of naming the new element goes to the person who discovered it. While it may sound straightforward, there have been periods of tension as new elements were being discovered, particularly between 1960 and 1990 which some nuclear chemists refer to as the “Transfermium Wars”. Transfermium refers to “after element 100” since the elements in question were the synthetic elements 104 – 109. Both the United States and Russia were embroiled in a race to isolate the remaining synthetic elements. This led to both countries isolating three of the six remaining elements - 104, 105 and 106 - around the same time. Each country claimed naming rights and disregarded the other country’s suggested names. Ultimately, IUPAC distributed naming rights among both countries.

pageData.desc: A stylized section of the periodic table of the elements.
pageData.altText: A stylized section of the periodic table of the elements.

pageData.text: is often credited with creating the first of the ; however, the organization of the modern periodic table did not begin or end with his table. In the early 1800s, Jöns Jakob Berzelius made a major discovery that would lead the way for scientists to examine the possibility of a systematic organization of the elements. He published a list of for elements known to him at that time. This new information and the properties of the elements prompted scientists to attempt to organize the elements.One of the first organizational schemes was designed by . He noticed a pattern of similar properties among some groups of three elements, which he called triads. He also saw that the average of the weights of the lightest and heaviest elements in a triad were equal or close to the weight of the middle element. Among the known elements, however, Dobereiner was able to find only three working triads, and he was unable to show how any unknown elements might later fit into his scheme. His theory faded, but his idea of patterns among elements endured.A geology professor, , published a list of known elements in what many consider to be the first periodic table. His table consisted of the elements ordered by atomic weight wrapped around a cylinder in a spiral. Those elements on the same vertical line had similar properties. De Chancourtois’s table focused mainly on physical properties and included some ions and compounds in addition to elements. His table did not predict any unknown elements and largely was ignored until the work of Dmitri Mendeleev.

took a different approach to classifying the elements. After arranging the elements by atomic weight he saw a repeating pattern in which every eighth element possessed similar properties. He considered this octet arrangement of elements to be similar to a musical octave. His idea did not gain much support for quite some time but was one of the precursors to the work of Mendeleev.Some historians speculate that Mendeleev set out to organize the elements, realizing like other chemists of his time that there must be some correlation between their mass and their properties. To find the key to the pattern, he created his own periodic table card set, listing all known information about each element on a card and then trying different ways of arranging the cards. Mendeleev ordered his elements by atomic weight and then grouped them so that chemical and physical properties were similar among groups. In arranging the known elements sequentially by atomic weight, he noticed that some of the elements did not match the physical and chemical characteristics of the groups into which they fell. He moved these elements to other groups until the physical and chemical characteristics matched. In doing so, he created empty spaces in his table. Later, Mendeleev hypothesized that there were undiscovered elements that would fit into the available spaces and he predicted their chemical and physical properties. Many of these predictions proved accurate when the elements were later discovered. Our modern periodic table exists because of this pioneering work.

pageData.question: While trying to organize the elements, Mendeleev had empty spaces where no elements seemed to fit. What did Mendeleev hypothesize?

options.text: Undiscovered elements would fit into the spaces.
De Chancourtois’ periodic table made more sense than his.
Dobereiner’s periodic table made more sense than his.
Rocks or minerals would fit into the spaces.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Mendeleev hypothesized that there were undiscovered elements that would fit into the available spaces.

pageData.question: Mendeleev used what characteristic(s) to organize the elements on his periodic table?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Mendeleev used the elements’ mass and chemical properties to organize a periodic table of elements.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Some historians speculate that Mendeleev set out to organize the elements, realizing like other chemists of his time that there must be some correlation between their mass and their properties. To find the key to the pattern, he created his own periodic table card set, listing all known information about each element on a card and then trying different ways of arranging the cards. He moved these elements to other groups until the physical and chemical characteristics matched. In doing so, he created empty spaces in his table, which he hypothesized would eventually be filled by elements yet to be discovered.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Some historians speculate that Mendeleev set out to organize the elements, realizing like other chemists of his time that there must be some correlation between their mass and their properties. To find the key to the pattern, he created his own periodic table card set, listing all known information about each element on a card and then trying different ways of arranging the cards. He moved these elements to other groups until the physical and chemical characteristics matched. In doing so, he created empty spaces in his table, which he hypothesized would eventually be filled by elements yet to be discovered.

pageData.text: Mendeleev’s is not, however, the same periodic table used by chemists today. Further discoveries and innovations have led to its expansion and modification. Especially important discoveries include the noble gases by and , the atomic numbers (the current criterion for organization) by and the addition of the actinide and lanthanide series.The modern periodic table organizes in horizontal rows, called periods, in order of increasing atomic number. As before, elements are also organized in a vertical column, called a family or group, when they share similar physical or chemical properties. Elements with similar properties occur predictably as a result of regular variations in the electronic structures of atoms. Predictable, regular variation, with the tendency to reoccur at regular intervals, is called

pageData.title: Activity Details
pageData.text: It is recommended to have a lab partner or group to share and compare results with. Ask your instructor how he or she would want you to exchange information. An important part of science is the scientific discussion that occurs to determine the meaning of the results or during the development of new theory. It is through this type of discussion that our understanding of scientific results is improved. This communication of results and discussion of their meaning will be practiced in this activity.

In Activity 1, use periodicity to arrange a set of colored cards based on their appearance, and then make inferences about how the next column of cards would appear. Compare your arrangement to that of a classmate and then make inferences about cards missing from the classmate’s arrangement.In Activity 2, use periodicity to arrange a set of element information cards based on their properties of the elements and then make inferences about the properties of the next row of cards. Compare your arrangement to that of a classmate and make inferences about cards missing from the classmate’s arrangement.In Activity 3, arrange a set of element information cards based on their and number of valence electrons of each element. Generalize periodic trends for atomic radius, first ionization energy and electronegativity.In Activity 4, use the data from the element information cards arranged in Activity 3 to prepare a visual representation (graph, illustration, or model) depicting periodic trends for atomic radius, ionization energy, and electronegativity.

options.text: Predictable, regular variation, with the tendency to reoccur at regular intervals.
The horizontal arrangement of elements on the periodic table.
The vertical arrangement of elements on the periodic table.
Predictable gaps in the arrangement of components of a system.
The cycle of observation and experimentation in the scientific method.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: It is through scientific discussion that our understanding of scientific results is improved. This communication of results and discussion of their meaning will be practiced in this activity.

options.text: The horizontal arrangement of elements by increasing atomic number.
The vertical arrangement of elements by increasing atomic number.
The horizontal arrangement of elements by chemical properties.
The vertical arrangement of elements by chemical properties.
The horizontal arrangement of elements by decreasing electronegativity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Periods are horizontal rows of elements in order of increasing atomic number.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An important part of science is the scientific discussion that occurs to determine the meaning of the results or during the development of new theory. The modern periodic table organizes elements in horizontal rows, called periods, in order of increasing atomic number. As before, elements are also organized in a vertical column, called a family or group, when they share similar physical or chemical properties. Elements with similar properties occur predictably as a result of regular variations in the electronic structures of atoms. Periodicity, then, is predictable, regular variation, with the tendency to reoccur at regular intervals.

Periodicity, then, is predictable, regular variation, with the tendency to reoccur at regular intervals.

pageData.desc: This map outlines the workflow for Activities 1 and 2 for this investigation. Before starting any activities, organize the three card decks. In Activity 1, you will arrange Card Deck 1 by two characteristics and observe trends in the arrangement. Then, you will remove two cards from the arrangement, take a photo, and exchange photos with a classmate. Finally, you will identify the missing cards from your classmate’s arrangement. In Activity 2, you will remove two predetermined cards from Card Deck 2. Then, you will arrange the deck by two characteristics and observe trends in the arrangement. Next, you will incorporate the two removed cards back into the arrangement and remove two different cards from the arrangement. Then, you will take a photo and exchange arrangement photos with a classmate. Finally, you will identify the missing cards from your classmate’s arrangement.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: The horizontal rows of the periodic table are known by what term?
Elements in the same group on the periodic table share what characteristic(s) in common?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the Procedure.
Obtain all materials.

Make sure each deck is complete and organized separately:
  1. Card Deck 1: 25 colorful cards with shapes and numbers
  2. Card Deck 2: 34 cards with information but no names or atomic numbers
  3. Card Deck 3: 34 cards with element information, names, and atomic numbers
Remove the cover card from Card Deck 1 and randomize the set. Then return the cover card to the deck and set aside.
Repeat the preceding step for Card Deck 2 and Card Deck 3.
Clear a flat workspace using a table (or the floor, if necessary). Workspace should be at least 22 × 26".

In Activity 1, you will organize the cards in Card Deck 1 according to two characteristics of your choice. You will then remove two cards at random from the arrangement, photograph the arrangement, and exchange arrangement photos with a classmate. You will then attempt to identify the missing cards in your classmate’s photo.
Examine all of the cards in Card Deck 1 and note the various characteristics of the cards.
Choose one characteristic (color, shape, number, etc.) and arrange the cards according to the chosen characteristic. This may involve grouping or ordering, depending on the characteristic chosen.
Record this characteristic in the Notes section.
Put the cards back into one pile.
Choose another characteristic of the cards and arrange the cards according to the chosen characteristic. This may involve grouping or ordering, depending on the characteristic chosen.
Record this second characteristic in the Notes section.
Arrange the cards in a way that incorporates both characteristics listed in the Notes section.
Observe any trends or patterns associated with the way the cards are organized. Record these trends or patterns in the Notes section.
Photograph the arrangement of Card Set 1 as a record of your work.
Without disturbing the arrangement, remove two cards at random. Place these two cards aside.
Photograph the arrangement of Card Set 1 (showing blank space for the missing cards).
Share the photograph with a classmate according to your instructor’s directions.
Photograph the two cards set aside in Step 10. Share the photograph with a classmate according to your instructor’s directions.
Gather the cards for Card Deck 1 and put them away.
Obtain and open the photograph showing a classmate’s arrangement of Card Deck 1 and try to determine which cards are missing from his arrangement. Record this prediction in the Notes section.
Obtain and open the photograph showing the same classmate’s missing cards. Record the features from the missing cards in the Notes Section.

In Activity 2, you will organize the cards in Card Deck 2 according to two characteristics of your choice. You will then remove two cards at random from the arrangement, photograph the arrangement, and exchange arrangement photos with a classmate. You will then attempt to identify the missing cards in your classmate’s photo.
Examine all of the cards in Card Deck 2 and become familiar with their similarities and differences.
Remove the card with Atomic Mass = 1 and the card with Atomic Mass = 4. Set them aside until Step 8.
Choose one property on the cards that would allow cards to be placed into groups. Record this property in the Notes section.
Stack cards into groups using the property recorded in the previous step.
Choose another property on the cards that would allow cards to be ordered within each stack. Record this property in the Notes section.
Spread each stack of <button class='glossary-text'>element</button> cards out into an ordered column using the property recorded in the previous step.
Observe any trends or patterns associated with the way the cards are organized. Record the trends or patterns in the Notes section.
Pick up the two cards set aside earlier (in Step 2). Incorporate these two cards into the arrangement using the patterns or trends observed in the previous step.
These two cards may not fit neatly into the existing arrangement. Use your best judgment to determine their placement.
Photograph the arrangement of Card Set 2 as a record of your work.
It may be necessary to photograph the right and left halves separately.
Without disturbing the arrangement, remove two cards at random. Place these two cards aside.
Photograph the arrangement of Card Set 2 (showing blank space for the missing cards).
It may be necessary to photograph the right and left halves separately.
Share the photograph with a classmate according to your instructor’s directions.
Photograph the two cards set aside in Step 10 and share the photograph with a classmate according to your instructor’s directions.
Gather the cards for Card Deck 2 and put them away.
Obtain and open the photograph showing a classmate’s arrangement of Card Deck 2 and try to determine which cards are missing from this arrangement. Record this prediction in the Notes section.
Obtain and open the photograph showing the same classmate’s missing cards. Record the features from the missing cards in the Notes section.
In Activity 3, you will organize the cards in Card Deck 3 according to the number of valence electrons in order to build the <button class='glossary-text'>Periodic Table</button>.
Examine all of the cards in Card Deck 3, paying attention to the properties listed.
Remove the Hydrogen and Helium cards. Set them aside until Step 7.
Stack the cards into eight groups on the basis of their number of valence electrons.

Place the stacks in an ordered row so that the <button class='glossary-text'>elements</button> with one valence electron are to the left and the elements with eight valence electrons are to the right.
Within each of the stacks, arrange the cards from lowest atomic number to highest atomic number.
Spread each stack of element cards out into an ordered column so that the card with the lowest atomic number is at the top of the column. There should be four rows and eight columns.
Pick up the two cards set aside earlier (in Step 2). Place the Hydrogen card above the Lithium card (on the top left).
Place the Helium card above the Neon card (on the top right). Determine which Helium card properties match those of other cards in this vertical column. Record the similarities in the Notes section.
Observe any trends or patterns associated with the organization of cards and record them in the Notes section.
Photograph the arrangement of Card Deck 3 as a record of your work.
Collect Card Deck 3 in order of increasing atomic number for use during Activity 4.
It may be necessary to photograph the right and left halves separately.
In Activity 4, you will use the data from Card Deck 3 to prepare a visual representation of periodic trends for three different characteristics.

Use the data from Card Deck 3 to prepare a visual representation (graph, illustration, or model) depicting periodic trends for each of the following:
  1. Atomic radius
  2. First ionization energy
  3. Electronegativity
Submit electronic files or photographs of the representations prepared during this activity according to your instructor’s directions.
If you are unsure about what visual representation to create, use a chemistry textbook (or other resources) for ideas of how others have chosen to illustrate periodic trends.

pageData.title: Atomic Mass
text: Why are the elements no longer organized by atomic mass?
What pattern is there with regard to valence electrons, oxygen bonding ratio and electron configuration?
Where in the periodic table are the elements with the largest atomic radii? Where are those with the smallest atomic radii?
How does atomic radius change from left to right across a period, or row, in the periodic table?
How does atomic radius change from top to bottom down a group, family or column in the periodic table?
Why does this trend exist in atomic radii?
How do the atomic radii of the following elements compare? Which is larger?

pageData.text: a. Se and Br
b. Rb and Cs
c. Ca and As
d. Sn and Pb

pageData.title: Ionization Energy
text: Where in the periodic table are the elements with the greatest first ionization energies? Where are those with the smallest first ionization energies?
How does first ionization energy change from left to right across a period, or row, in the periodic table?
How does first ionization energy change from top to bottom down a group, family or column in the periodic table?
What is the relationship between the trend in ionization energy and the trend in atomic radius? Why does this relationship exist?
How does the first ionization energy of the following elements compare? Which is higher?

pageData.text: a. Se and Br
b. Cl and I
c. Ca and As
d. Sr and Rb

pageData.title: Electronegativity
text: Where in the periodic table are the elements with the greatest electronegativity? Where are those with the least electronegativity?
How does electronegativity change from left to right across a period, or row, in the periodic table?
How does electronegativity change from top to bottom down a group, family or column in the periodic table?
How does the electronegativity of the following elements compare? Which is higher?

pageData.text: a. Se and Br
b. Cl and I
c. Ca and As
d. Sr and Rb

In Activity 1, you will arrange Card Deck 1 by two characteristics and observe trends in the arrangement. Then, you will remove two cards from the arrangement, take a photo, and exchange photos with a classmate. Finally, you will identify the missing cards from your classmate’s arrangement. In Activity 2, you will remove two predetermined cards from Card Deck 2. Then, you will arrange the deck by two characteristics and observe trends in the arrangement. Next, you will incorporate the two removed cards back into the arrangement and remove two different cards from the arrangement. data.title: Alexandre Béguyer de Chancourtois
data.content: Published a list of known elements in what many consider to be the first periodic table, the table consisted of the elements ordered by atomic weight wrapped around a cylinder in a spiral

data.title: Atomic weight (atomic mass)
data.content: The average mass of atoms of an element, generally found under the atomic symbol

data.title: Dmitri Mendeleev
data.content: Often given credit for creating the first periodic table

data.title: Element
data.content: Pure substance consisting only of atoms that all have the same numbers of protons in their nuclei

data.title: Henry Moseley
data.content: Contributed to the addition of the actinide and lanthanide series on the periodic table

data.title: Johann Dobereiner
data.content: He was unable to show how any unknown elements might later fit into his scheme, but the idea that elements followed pattern endured

data.title: John Newland
data.content: Noticed a repeating pattern repeating pattern in which every eighth element possessed similar properties

data.title: Lord Rayleigh (John William Strutt)
data.content: Made important discoveries about noble gases led to expansion of the periodic table

data.title: Periodic table
data.content: An organized array of all the chemical elements in order of increasing atomic number

data.title: Periodicity
data.content: Predictable, regular variation, with the tendency to reoccur at regular intervals

data.title: William Ramsay
data.content: Discoveries regarding atomic numbers, which is the current criterion for organization of the periodic table
